headline: Request IP Australia confirms a registered design is valid
description: Request IP Australia examines and certifies a registered design to secure full protection

usageInfo.name: Disclaimer and Feedback Policy
usageInfo.text: This IP First Response website has been designed to help IP rights holders navigate IP infringement and enforcement by making it visible, accessible, and to provide information about the factors involved in pursuing different options. It does not provide legal, business or other professional advice, and none of the content should be regarded as recommending a specific course of action. We welcome any feedback via our IP First Response feedback form and by emailing us.

isPartOf.name: IP First Response
isPartOf.description: A first port of call for businesses to easily understand complex intellectual property issues.

mainEntity.name: Request IP Australia confirms a registered design is valid
mainEntity.description: Request IP Australia examines and certifies a registered design to secure full protection

mainEntity.name: How to proceed with Request IP Australia confirms a registered design is valid

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Ability to pay the examination fee.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Be prepared to respond to an examination report which may require providing additional evidence or submissions to address any issues raised.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Consider whether to get help from an IP lawyer or IP attorney.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Keep copies of all correspondence and the certificate of examination.

acceptedAnswer.text:
* Examination could lead to you needing to amend your registered design.
* Examination could lead to your registered design being revoked.
* Failing to pay your share of the examination fee (when examination is requested by a third party) will cause your registration to cease.
* A certificate of examination related to a registered design does not guarantee success; enforcing a design may still be costly.

* Your registered design is certified and becomes enforceable.
* You apply to amend your registered design so it can be certified, a list of allowable amendments can be found in the relevant section of the Designs Manual: [22.2.1. Amending an application: Amendments that are allowable | IPA Manuals](https://manuals.ipaustralia.gov.au/design/amendments-that-are-allowable)
* Your registered design is revoked because you were unable to overcome objections or other matters raised by the ~~E~~xaminer within the relevant time limit (whether through submissions, amendments to your registration, lodgement of evidence or other steps).
* You do not pay your share of the fee for a third-party examination and your registered design ceases.
IP Australia’s fee schedule lists the owner’s examination fee at $500 (effective 1 October 2024). If a third party requests examination, you and the requester split the fee.

mainEntity.name: How much time might be involved?

acceptedAnswer.text: IP Australia reports an average wait of up to 12  weeks from request to decision. If you have urgent reasons (for example, pending litigation), you may request expedited examination. IP Australia offers this as a business process and timelines can vary, but reports are often issued within 4–8 weeks. Preparing evidence or amendments may add extra work hours.

* The registered design owner or an exclusive licensee who wants to enforce the right.
* Any other person (for example, a competitor) can request examination.

* Design right owner.
* IP Australia’s design examiner makes the examination decision.
* Optional: third‑party requester of examination.
* Optional: IP lawyer or patent attorney.
